reviewText:
I love this game!
It offers simple but intriguing controls which in later levels must be used with precision
The graphics are pretty good and there are enough levels and gamemodes to keep you entertained for a while
Even though the maps can be a bit repetitive in how they are built they still vary the conditions in which you play
Customisation is huge with different guns and gear for different situations
Being stuck on a level for a while and finally getting through it is a great feeling which this game achieves in the players

Highly recommend it to everyone who likes stategy games and those who do not want a game overly complicated

(they should add multiplayer where one team plays as the terrorist and the other counter-terrorists, also a steam workshop community maps and wepons addon, that would be cool)

reviewText: I have been playn this game for a little while now. Wish I would have started play'n it alot sooner. Its awesome IMO. The game is easy to pick up and learn. Its all about loadouts and team tactics in a SRT/BC format. The DLC is kinda what ever but it is a must if you are going for 100% achievements. The game is highly replayable and has some semi tough difficulty settings. Silver (the game currency) is a little hard to make a ton but once you getr your first team/squad to all rank 30 its not to bad. The game also features a hardcore mode so when you die ....well your dead I for one like this feature in alot of games. So if your looking for a diamond in the rough its safe to say pick this game up.

reviewText: I wish this game had physics. I wish the bad guys would fall over like real bad guys instead of just slump over. This game does not feel 100% realistic. Maybe 83% realistic. (Okay, 84%). This game feels like something from the year 1999. You shoot bad guys and they just sort of slump over and are stuck in whatever last frame of animation they end up in before your next turn starts. It doesn't feel authentic. The game is interesting but I get it, it's a simulator first and then a game. Like, the kind of simulator you would use to train at work if you were a Navy Seal or Special Ops-type. If those jobs meant working in an office. I recommend this game but Jagged Alliance and Frozen Synapse are 2 much MUCH better versions of this game.

reviewText:
I played the mobile version of this game because I couldn't wait for the PC version to come out.  Now that it has and I've played it, am I satisfied?  Oh yes.  Yes I am.

This version is even better than the mobile one!

Think of this as XCOM meets Rainbow 6.  You start by choosing your squad from amongst the world's best special forces.  Then you get to go into the missions, planning each stage, and then hitting a button to watch it all unfold in front of you.  Went by too fast?  Then just watch the instant replay.  The ability to improve the skills of your operators is also a nice touch.  Makes you really start to care about them and their welfare.

Love the customization of weapons and armour, too.

If anything, this game is priced too low.  Yes, I said too low.  I would have paid 30 bucks no problem.

Well done, Mighty Rabbit!!

reviewText: Great turn based tactial game!  You can create a number of squads from different real life special forces units. reviewText: I didn't know this was an iOS game...until a few minutes after playing the game that is. I got this thinking it would be fun to play the Spetznaz, but as far as i can tell there is literally no reason to pick anyone but the American special forces because they all speak in American accented english, and the only thing worse to me than a baddly accented cast is one that isn't even accented at all. Hell, they could have plugged voice lines in to google translate and had the voice actors say their lines in broken Russian and German for all i care, i wouldn't have noticed and it would have made me happy to know they at least made them speak the right langauge.\n\nNow that all the hate is out of the way, for what irked me it was a simple and somewhat fun game for the twenty minutes i gave it. I wish it was fleshed out more, maybe an economy or base building, but since its not i can't really say its worth the $14 i paid for it. If your going ot port an iOS game to the PC, you have to not only change it to fit the controls, but to also fit the price your asking for, if it was a better version of the iOS game and not just the same than maybe, but since its the same they should have priced it like it is, as a fun little I-pad game you play now and then, not like a full game your meant to play for more than a few weeks just a few weeks before going Nope

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong the game is fun but there are problems as well. I will update my review if they update their game. The attachments for the weapons are really unbalanced there is one vest you can buy that give your men something like +175 health while the others for the same price will give them +5-10. I don't know if you had to pay for this vest in the phone version or what? Plus many more weird things. When I select a different trigger the picture doesn't show it on the gun. Silencers lower damage come on in Call of Duty that makes sense but this is a simulator. Many weird things with the attachments.

Weapons are weird as well. You can only buy two weapons at the beginning and even after unlocking a third the gun your guys start with is better... So I'm not sure wny they would give you an option to buy a new crappier one?

Tool tips would be nice. There are 6 classes but you can see the differences while lining them up at the door. It would be nice if you could tell this. There are a lot of places more tooltips would come in handy.

If you your walk up to a door they open it. I wish there was a way for them to sit next to it without opening it. Not a huge deal you just after to remember this when telling them where to go.

They also need to put a restart put in the game. If you lose a couple guys you have to either finish the map, kill your other guys, or get out of the game to restart. As soon as your are done with the map you can restart so its not like they don't let you replay the maps.

Overall this is a fun game. But I think if I could go back in time I would have waited to see if they patch it first.

reviewText:
First of all, this is my first review, so if I wrote it in the wrong way, tell me how to write a proper review.

Breach and clear is a turn based strategy game in which you control 4 spec ops troops and either eliminate all terrorists in the map, defuse the bomb, or get to the extraction point. There will not be multiple objectives in one mission.

Pros:

High Customisation. in guns you can attach lights, IR systems, sights, different triggers, and gas systems and muzzle attachments, note that you can't customize all of them on all guns. You can change the kind of armor they wear, helmets, etc.

Not too hard (but not too easy)

EXTREMELY enjoyable

Good graphics




Cons:

Gameplay gets kind of dull, since there is very little plot (what you get is something like :A small group of terrorists have taken over a small american buisness in afganistan. Clear out the building)

Extremely cheap voice acting (all the different special forces all have the same voice acting, Spetsnaz speaking english like americans, that doesn't sound right does it? Where are the SAS's british accents?)

Voice acting lines are few and dull, when one of your guys is getting killed, I excpect him to say something like; I need support! Or something like that, instead, they say nothing.

No multiplayer at all, I hope the devs are working on it, I'd also like a level editor or something like that.


Overall I would say 8/10

reviewText: One of the better tactical games out there.  Several out there will tell you otherwise because of a few reasons.  Some complain about the graphics being dated, well I am an old school gamer from the Atari 2600 days so lemme say that great graphics do NOT make great gameplay.  I'd rather have a blocky ugly game that plays great than some photo-realistic crap that simply isn't fun just pretty to look at.  Another group of players will say there's no varity in weapons, equipment, etc.  Folks being a former active duty U.S. Marine I can tell ya that in the real world you don't always get varity"  you get what your issued and make it work.  You improvise

reviewText: I haven't played too many turn-based strategy games, xcom, arma tactics, frozen synapse, skulls of the shogun... but I don't like this game better than any of the others. There is no background story around the various missions, the user interface isn't very polished, the movement system is limited, the character development not too interesting, the graphics just ok, and the maps quite small.\nThis game is an interesting mix of various features found it other games, but that's the only thing I find likeable about the game. It's not a bad game if you really like turn-based strategy I guess, there is enough material to keep you busy for a while. But I wouldn't recommend this game to a friend.
voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: While the concept is good, the actual execution is lacking. Many of the expected tactical options are either missing or only unlocked at higher levels, and it often comes down to either hiding and sniping behind cover or advancing straight at the enemy. The first few maps have an intenseness that is needed, but as you progress to bigger, more open maps, it becomes a chore to clear out the area and there is little in the way of breaching.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A simple tactical game. Dont go beyond that. Does not come close to its competitor Frozen Synapse, but delivers what  promises in parts, getting impossible not to compare each one.

Despite having a description on page extremely tempting, promising a highly tactical and complex game, is hardly so.

Strategies and options are simple, basically limiting the positioning of soldiers and their handling in each phase. You simply enter the room and see the shooting happen. You can break down doors, throw tactical devices like grenades and flashbangs, and choose which way to look. Nothing else. The game is an infinite looping entering the room, get lucky for the soldiers first shoot the enemies and start all over again.

A typical game for mobile phones that was poorly ported to PC. It is very clear looking at the layouts and menus of the game, very badly adapted.

Some soldiers have certain specific skills for each class, such as locking doors and having improved reaction time but also by the structure of the game such skills make little difference in the time of action.

The graphics are typically mobile. Few animations make the game boring (like terrorists falling in the same position) and the sound effects are amateurs.

Despite being a mobile game badly ported to PC it's a little amusing. There are options to purchase equipment and a wide customization possibilities. Probably as the game grow with their development (giving more respect to the pc's users) it can become better.

Briefly comparing the competitor, are almost two different games. The complexity and tactical strategy are much deeper in Frozen Synapse.

I'm not recommending the game, I suggest you wait more to spend your hard earned money and go for Frozen Synapse.

Give a score 06/10 with a certain twinge of conscience.

I hope you enjoy my review, any questions just ask in my profile.

reviewText:
10/10

I loved the old Police Quest: Swat games, Jagged Alliance, XCOM, Door kickers, Dead State, Omerta, Shadowrun etc etc and I can say that by far this is my favorite plan-n-play style of game.

The only thing that would make this game better in my eyes  would be the ability to pause anytime you want and change the tasked orders. (Like Door Kickers or Jagged Alliance 2 Back in Action) It's a bit more realistic when you can pause and give your squad new commands instead of watching them take 10 bullets in the back before dying because you forgot to set a squad member to check a corner or an enemy pops out of a door right after you pass it.

reviewText:
In spite of this being ported from Ipad/android, it's a good game, more or less complex.

+ Nice concurrent turn based close combat strategy (reminicent of Frozen Synapse)
+ Nice looking graphics, still light enough to run in any system.
+ Great tactical gameplay.
- For game design reasons, you only use american guns, even when playing with german or russian squads. (No H&K, no Kalashnikov!!) This is built into the game, since guns are level-locked and unrealistically upgraded. Not a bad thing in itself, but game breaker if you are a gun nut like me.
- It feels" like a tablet game. Again

reviewText:
Impressions of this game so far are not great.

Controls seem more than a bit clunky and cumbersome. Graphics aren't great, it looks pretty brutal (for modern gaming standards) in my opinion. Similar games like Doorkickers use minimal artstyles and graphics but they definitely looked and felt a whole lot better/polished than Breach & Clear; Breach & Clear seems to try to look good, but doesn't really pull it off.

Worse of all, I found myself bored within the first few minutes of opening the game. That doesn't necessarily mean that all of it will be, but I definitely don't feel invested the same way I was with Doorkickers.

I bought this game because of the positve reviews and because I LOVED Doorkickers. This definitely is in the same exact vein, but so far hasn't excited me. I'm not going to count it out yet, but first impressions aren't great so far.

I guess the gist of my review could be as follows:

If you're interested in this game but haven't played Doorkickers, go buy/play Doorkickers.
If you're still interested in this game and own/have played Doorkickers, you're likely better off to go back to playing Doorkickers...

reviewerDisplayName: The Mother Fucking Major F R E T
reviewText:
TL;DR get Doorkickers instead

For five bucks more you could get Doorkickers which has better gameplay, way more unique levels+campaigns, more modes (hostage rescue, VIP escort, heists in addition to bomb defusal and just search and destroy), doesn't recycle maps nearly as much (to be fair Doorkickers does recycle some levels), an in game editor allowing you to create your own levels and mod support. This game is $4 on the Apple Store and the only difference (apart from it being on a PC rather than an Apple iPhone/Pad/whatever) it has in app purchases.

Also, the developers have the guts to claim that real life Special Forces units use this as an educational tool for real life in the intro ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQjqhY6NPIQ ). So your telling me that this game, which started life as an iOS game, is considered the 'Most Advanced Training Tool Avaliable', over Vitural Battlespace 1 or 2 (which was developed specifically for militaries to train soldiers), or even ARMA or just actually getting of your ♥♥♥♥ and doing actual training? I admit I have no back ground in the military but I'd bet my entire bank account that the claims made in the intro video is complete B U L L S H I T. If it wasn't for this claim, I would have probably just kept the game as I bought it on sale, but if the Devs want to lie to my face like that, I'm taking a refund.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Breach & Clear is an actual training manual for rifle-team leaders.  The scenarios are serious, realistic opportunities for you to learn how to set up a mission team, how to position them for maximum mutual cover, how to carry out a mission without loss of members of your team and a constant improvement of real-life skills from scenario to scenario.  I recommend this for SERIOUS military types who want to improve or develop abilities to lead and plan for real rifle-team missions.  A+ / 5*

reviewText: I thought this was a tactical squad combat game. To be a tactical squad combat game certain elements must be present. Such as the ability to change stance, from prone, to kneeling and standing, and receive modifiers to accuracy based on stance. Also select fire mode which also modifies accuracy versus rounds fired. This game has neither. Its very arcade. For those who played Brigade 7.62, or Jagged Alliance Back in Action, Soldiers at War, Soldiers of Anarchy, X com, Hired guns, Silent Storm etc... you will be disappointed. This is a 3D arcade game. Nothing more. My bad in a way for not researching more. But the pictures and vid files really make the game look detailed and tactical in a way similar to the games I listed above. But it is not, it only masquerades as a tactical 3rd person POV squad level game, oh did I mention it is very arcade?

reviewText:
So I bought this game for $5. Played one full hour and am completely hooked! This game is Frozen Synapse with amazing graphics, in depth tactics, but minus the time manipulation.

The weapon customization is very good. There is a large amount of weapons and attachments to buy with the in game money. Along with gear and camo.

Your team members gain XP, and through leveling up you can customize each character to play as you wish under specific skills.

All in all this is the best $5 I have spent on a game in a very long time, and I give this game a high reccomendation to those of you that enjoy a fast pace turn by turn strategy game.

reviewText:
I don't understand why there is so much positive reviews, I can only explain this with fact that there is not much games like this, so people have very low expectations and happy to have any kind of game like this.

This game has same problem, as all recent attempts to make remake of Jagged Alliance, or Brigade E5/7.62 High Calibre series game. Maybe even worse. Much worse.

Dull models, dull art, dull animation, dull and ugly UI, non intuitive controls/UI. White standard fonts without outlining, in the dull gray boxes. Upon realizing mechanics of this game, that in fact it's very bad turn based game with square grid, and not smart pause planing game like previously mentioned - you will just hate it.


My recommendation - if you want recent good game in this genre, you better go and get Doorkickers, they maybe be 2D, and look like some silly casual arcade/puzzle in a first glance, but in the end, it's much better looking game and playable game. It has its own flaws, but at least it's playable and fun game.

If you want smart-pause tactical 3D game, get latest Jagged Aliance remake - it suck because performance issue, because it's sometimes unpredictable when things that happen are non-intuitive and not really realistic (acting not according to real life logic), and annoying in general, yet it's still better game, you can have at least some fun.

If you want turn-based square grid tactical game, go and get - XCOM: Enemy Unknown (yeah, shame that this game is absolutely not even close by quality to XCOM, i would like XCOM quality game but more serious with little bit more realism, and without aliens, but about special forces... but no luck, this game is not like this).

Now thinking, even Rainbow Six (the original one) would be a better game (you can plan your actions, and then just watch how everything goes), and even maybe more reasonable tactical simulation (wtf is with this intro, saying that this game is used by military to train? is this a joke?)

reviewText:
Breach and Clear is not the kind of game you would expect it to be, walk into room, shoot things, kill things is what you would have expected to be doing with your time on Breach and Clear, but as soon as you begin the training mission it becomes very apararent that storm into a run guns blazing is not the only way to do things.

You get to create a squad from seven different military forces (SAS, Seals, Spetznaz etc) and create the characters from scratch naming them and giving them a specific role within the team (medic, team leader, weapons sergeant etc) and as you play missions with them they earn XP and level up, you then earn points which you allocate to a specific skill tree on that character, relatively simple to anyone who has played a game about gear or character progression.

The game is very user friendly, after playing the short 5 minute tutorial I felt like an expert, the key important features and commands you can issue to your squad are used repeatedly in the tutorial to get you used to them and the features that arne't reinforced are very easily and quickly learned, whether you want that soldier to go in that door or one soldier to throw a flashbang then the other storm the room and take out the hostiles, if you want to do it you can!

Another feature that makes this game well worth the money (grab it for $3.50 now while you can) is the endless replayability, make new squads then replay each mission on the hardest difficulty experimenting with the different mechanics each time you play it!

Overall Breach and Clear is quite frankly perfect, there is nothing wrong it in my eyes which earns it a
10/10
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Basically, it's a simplified version of Frozen Synapse. It's tons of fun and very well polished for a mobile port. Most things in this game are done right, but there are a few huge flaws about that keep it from greatness. First off, there's no multiplayer mode... Really!? A turn-based strategy has no multiplayer gamemode!? Secondly, the camera controls are a bit wonky. You'll get accustomed to it, but it just feels off. Finally, there isn't a story. You're just dropped into singleplayer missions. There are 3 game modes and about about 95 missions in all, which will give you about 15 hours of game time, but they dont have much replayability, so once you play them, then they're done... I got it in the humble bundle and I can say it was easily worth that price. If you enjoy games like XCOM: Enemy Unknown, Frozen Synapse, or Jagged Alliance, then you have no excuse to not buy this game.

So, lets review.
Pros:
+Great addicting gameplay
+Large amount  of character and squad customization
+Decent visuals for a mobile port
+Good AI (on Hard and up)
+Large amount of missions

Cons:
-No story
-Wonky controls
-No multiplayer (Seriously?!)
-Missions can get repetitive
-Is a mobile port

Overall, I give this game a 7/10.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Bottom line is, that this is a fun game.

The downside is that it lacks complexity and gets old pretty quickly.  Sure, it's fun going through the missions and leveling up your team in their respective specializations and getting them new gear - but then what?

It's completely satisfying watching your team burst through a door and open up a can of whoopass on some unsuspecting misfits.

One of my main complaints about the gameplay, which may be a bit strange, but here it is:  You can see almost everything.  The only thing I have to wonder about is where the enemies are standing and which direction they are facing.  Surely things could be more interesting if I had a kind of blueprint of the building, and some not-so-trustworthy intel about what objects and obstacles may be where.  There's no peeking through windows or tiny spy cameras to get a better idea of what's on the other side of a door - it's all just there and you know where everything is.

I like the game, but I also want there to be more variables.  I know my team can breach and clear a room in seconds and shoot at anything that isn't themselves.  I want to make more decisions than stack order, and which door to open first.

reviewText:
Very polished tactical shooter in vain of Frozen Synapse. Decent customization even though the weapon and gear models look too similar. The weapons are balanced and there are several nice levels which can be enjoyed in 3 modes: Terrorist hunt (kill everybody), Bomb Defusal, survival/escape.

Graphics are decent but not eye-popping. Far from it, actually. The human models all look pretty much the same even if you select different characters. Mediocre at best and could have used a more vivid style and color palette.

The gameplay itself is turn based tactical battles. about 70% of the maps are indoors and use tight corridors and covers to keep the action pumping and the rest are outdoors which focus more on tactical play and choosing the best ways to strike.

Your squad of 4 (which you can create yourself and customize) level up as you gain more stars in missions and more XP. You also receive money to purchase new weapon upgrades and gear. You choose specifically which attribute to level up for each soldier (e.g. accuracy, speed, special ability, reaction etc.). This all helps to give the game longevity as well as harder difficulty settings which make the game much more demanding. I'd also like to note that the music is pretty cool.

I only wish there was a Restart Level" button in the pause menu because you need to go back to the main menu every time you choose to restart a level mid play.

All in all
date: a great bargain game and I'd say it's worth the full price even though there aren't many maps to play around in (there are new ones in a DLC though). But if you liked Frozen Synapse or want to give the games a try I think you'll like what you find here."

reviewText:
It's like SWAT but topdown. It brings good memories of tactical shooters. In a sesne this is a cross of XCOM with SWAT that turned out really good. At least that's what you'll feel at the beginning.

The most accurate description of this game is simplified top-down Rainbow Six sim. It has planning phase and execution phase. The game has three different game mods and they are entertaining at the beginning. However once you levelled up and bought good gear the challenge is no longer there.
It is a nice casual tactical sim, and breach and clear is very accurate name. All you do you breach and kill every poor soul around. There are no hostages to save, just a set of maps which become grounds for your tactical proving and killing skills.
In the absence of other alternatives and no desire to install the good old SWAT or Rainbow Six this will do, but don't expect a serious challenge.

Check out my other recommendations at
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ogrreview

reviewText:
Here's my review for, Breach & Clear !! **Early Review (2h gametime)** (7.6 out of 10.0) Overall.
****P.S****
If you want a fair and understandable negative review of this game read the one of 'Hyenaz' under the 'Helpful' reviews section in Store Page.

First Look: I didn't know what I'm about to witness of playing this game because I don't play simulator games so much. And especially tactical simulators.
My first run was near 2 hours.
I enjoyed this game and played the first mission, 5 times.
This game has very much to offer in terms of difficulties,missions,equippments,replayability,roles and ofcourse the main reason we purchae this game - tactics.

Gameplay:
Gameplay is very simple once you get used to it (I got used to it very fast and the tutorial was short and clear).
You have 4 characters, each one has same options and your role is to control them.
Besides that, there is the map itself which has easy acess to it (all you need to do is to move the cameras to your like, and manovering the soldiers on the map.)
Me as a hardcore tactical fan player I like to complete each mission on the best side so it took me around 15-20 minutes to complete a mission but after you do the same mission few times you do it faster and easier, and while still enjoying the mission. (8/10)
Cons: 1) Repetetive. 2) Full Members each mission (Annoying thing is you can only use all 4 members and not 2 or 1 or 3.)

Gameplay Styles:
1) Go loud and use breaching equippment / Loud weapons / Frag grenades etc
2) Go quiet and use silencers / lock picks / Flashbangs etc
3) Split your team through the rooms or work with all of them togather in each room.
4) Enjoy your time in investing and planning each mission to your liking and your own tactical strategy.
5) Difficulties - 5 Difficulties. (8.5/10)

Graphics:
Only saw one map so far but each room looks realistic with objects and tactical props (Walls/Big Closets etc that can block the A.I view so you can take cover behind them). (5/10)
Cons: 1) Lack of FPS. I get this is a sim game but they did add fps moments but I'm not feeling it cuz it's only in start/end of the mission. it would be better if we could switch between FPS and Map-Look modes of the cameras but oh well I guess it will take the tactical-strategy element of this game.

Equippment:
What can I say about this one..
4 Sections - Weapons , Gear , Headset , Consumeables.
There is an in-game store (Buy/Sell items from the money you've earned in each mission).
In each section there are many things to buy include Vests/Guns/Gun Parts/Suit Colours/Camos/Grenades etc..
Some of them are locked, you need to unlock them as you progress through the game.
There are also stats like Speed/Accuracy/Noise etc in some of the equippments. (7/10)
Cons: A bit more organized menu would be better, and there are some items I don't think I will use.

RPG Elements:
I should talk about this one cuz there are 6-7 special op teams you can choose from.
6 Roles to choose from and stick them to your soldier. (Not sure yet if each team has different roles or not)
Stats in equippment items and Money to invest in equippment.
Level up system to your soldiers. + XP.
Choose how your soldier will look like, and colour your guns. (6/10)

Enjoyment: (9/10) I'm sorry but this is one of the best tacticla simulators I've played.. I can invest all my time in this game figouring out different tactics/ways to approach into the enemy.
Repetetive: (6/10) It is but still you enjoy playing this game.
Replayability (9/10)
Frustraiton (1/10) - Early review but as long as you know what you do in this game.. You're fine.
Boredom (0/10) - Nothing so far.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I really want to like this game. I absolutely do. On paper, it seems to have everything I loved from games such as Jagged Alliance 2. First Look: I didn't know what I'm about to witness of playing this game because I don't play simulator games so much. And especially tactical simulators.
My first run was near 2 hours.
I enjoyed this game and played the first mission, 5 times.
This game has very much to offer in terms of difficulties,missions,equippments,replayability,roles and ofcourse the main reason we purchae this game - tactics.

Gameplay:
Gameplay is very simple once you get used to it (I got used to it very fast and the tutorial was short and clear).
You have 4 characters, each one has same options and your role is to control them.
Besides that, there is the map itself which has easy acess to it (all you need to do is to move the cameras to your like, and manovering the soldiers on the map.)
Me as a hardcore tactical fan player I like to complete each mission on the best side so it took me around 15-20 minutes to complete a mission but after you do the same mission few times you do it faster and easier, and while still enjoying the mission. (8/10)
Cons: 1) Repetetive. 2) Full Members each mission (Annoying thing is you can only use all 4 members and not 2 or 1 or 3.)

Gameplay Styles:
1) Go loud and use breaching equippment / Loud weapons / Frag grenades etc
2) Go quiet and use silencers / lock picks / Flashbangs etc
3) Split your team through the rooms or work with all of them togather in each room.
4) Enjoy your time in investing and planning each mission to your liking and your own tactical strategy.
5) Difficulties - 5 Difficulties. (8.5/10)

Graphics:
Only saw one map so far but each room looks realistic with objects and tactical props (Walls/Big Closets etc that can block the A.I view so you can take cover behind them). (5/10)
Cons: 1) Lack of FPS. I get this is a sim game but they did add fps moments but I'm not feeling it cuz it's only in start/end of the mission. it would be better if we could switch between FPS and Map-Look modes of the cameras but oh well I guess it will take the tactical-strategy element of this game.

Equippment:
What can I say about this one..
4 Sections - Weapons , Gear , Headset , Consumeables.
There is an in-game store (Buy/Sell items from the money you've earned in each mission).
In each section there are many things to buy include Vests/Guns/Gun Parts/Suit Colours/Camos/Grenades etc..
Some of them are locked, you need to unlock them as you progress through the game.
There are also stats like Speed/Accuracy/Noise etc in some of the equippments. (7/10)
Cons: A bit more organized menu would be better, and there are some items I don't think I will use.

RPG Elements:
I should talk about this one cuz there are 6-7 special op teams you can choose from.
6 Roles to choose from and stick them to your soldier. (Not sure yet if each team has different roles or not)
Stats in equippment items and Money to invest in equippment.
Level up system to your soldiers. + XP.
Choose how your soldier will look like, and colour your guns. (6/10)

Enjoyment: (9/10) I'm sorry but this is one of the best tacticla simulators I've played.. I can invest all my time in this game figouring out different tactics/ways to approach into the enemy.
Repetetive: (6/10) It is but still you enjoy playing this game.
Replayability (9/10)
Frustraiton (1/10) - Early review but as long as you know what you do in this game.. You're fine.
Boredom (0/10) - Nothing so far.

reviewText: I bought this game on sale because it looked pretty interesting, and it turned out to be one of the best games i've gotten in months. I downloaded it around midnight and figured i'd play 15-20 minutes to see how it was, and it was 4AM before I knew it. The gameplay is turn based, but once you choose where you want your soldiers to go, it becomes almost real time until your soldiers and the enemy stop shooting. You can make 4 man squads from multiple different special forces from around the world. There's tons of weapon attachments to customize an almost equally large amount of weapons, along with gear, like clothing, vests, helmets, etc, and those give different stat boosts or penalties. It's a great game and I can't really find anything about this game I don't like. I would definitely recommend giving this a try.

It puts you in command of an elite group of spec ops soldiers where you make all the calls from selecting the team, equipping them, sending them into harms way, and then rewarding them (i.e. skills points, new/better loadouts, etc.) for successful missions. reviewText:
Before I bought this game I had a quick scroll through reviews and most seemed to be one of two things.  This game is so much like X-COM  OR  This game is nothing like X-COM. I agree with the latter. Both games feature turn-based tactical combat and squad customisation but that is where the similarities end. Instead of individual turns for squad members, you plan out the paths for your men, then you press the breach button and each soldier runs forth like a human weapon, pouring shots into balaclava-clad enemies. Each planning phase takes minutes but the actual real time mission plays out in a matter of seconds.
I started up the game and was presented with a choice of various world special forces to play as; each with their own minor differences. I chose the SAS because it was the obvious choice (who wouldn't want to be the SAS). You get to travel to various parts of the world conducting three different brands of mission. You kill terrorists, you defuse a bomb and kill terrorists, you kill terrorists. Despite the lack of variation between the mission types the different environments are fun and the basic narratives provided give you some context as to why you are shooting these terrorists/seperatists/diisgruntled blokes. There is a rudimentary leveling up system in which you can upgrade the various skills of each of your 4 squad mates including their class specific skills. The game also has two currencies. You gain star ratings for missions and stars unlock new missions and new guns while silver allows you to buy new weapons, weapon customisations, aesthetics, new gear and consumables. It's simple system but works rather well.

TL:DR -

+ Be the SAS
+ Bring Freedom to Heathen Terrorists
+ 8.5/10
- No ability to stab people from the shadows
- Not enough Content

reviewText:
Just bought the game, REALLY enjoy it. Hopefully releasing onto PC means that you'll be supporting mods and adding more content for PC users. That said, as glad as I am that I bought it, it looks like it'll dry out pretty quick in the current state. Even starting with small things like expanding the marketplace content would go a long way. There aren't that many guns, and once you unlock all the weapons there's not much motivation to keep playing missions for the mission credits to buy things for your squads. As well, things like Multiplayer, a Level/Mission Editor and custom Campaign planner, Workshop Support, to name a few things, would all be very welcome additions. And probably necessary ones, before too long.

Otherwise, this is a solid foundation from which to work. Definitely worth the $10.00 I spent on the sale price, though I wouldn't recommend paying the full tab for it. Not -yet-, anyway.

Also, just on the side, please fix the CADPAT pattern. It looks more like AOR2 than CADPAT TW. I have my set hanging in the closet right next to me and there are none of those big off-white splotches you guys have textured it with.

reviewText:
If you are looking for deep tactical gameplay (as this game is advertised), then stay away, you won't find that here.

That said, the game still offers good casual entertainment, if you enjoy leveling up your guys and unlocking new equipment, give it a spin.

Quick run-down of the gameplay if you need help deciding if it is for you:

You first create a squad, you can decide between some well-known specops units like DEVGRU, SAS, KSK and so on. What unit you select decides the starter attributes of your guys, one will have their special ability trained up nice, other will have reaction time up, other accuracy etc.

Then you run through the missions, and I really mean run, as once you discover the one tactic that works 100% of the time against the AI, you'll just breeze through. Not much depth here, and the occasional weird glitch with your guys running backwards or facing a wall for no good reason.

Your guys gain experience, and you get money, so in-between you level up your guys (in the end, it doesnt matter much what squad you made, they'll all end up the same just look different), buy them some new weapons and gear.

You can upgrade weapons to modify their stats, but here you'll end up again with all the same upgrades as there is one good combination.

Sounds like not much, but it is a decent enough time-killer, pick it up when it is on sale.


In case 3d is not that important to you, I'd suggest to take a look at 'Door Kickers', that one has tactical gameplay down to perfection.

reviewText:
Great little game. I played the heck out of it on Android, and decided to get this on Steam even though I basically completed the game on Android. Decent PC port I'd have to say, though it is a fairly basic game as far as PC games are concerned with a focus on gameplay.

I'd compare it most to Frozen Synapse, though this with a real-life visual interface makes it better for me and it is also much less complex to get into. Some elements of XCOM thrown in for good measure as well.

Lots of content, that's one thing for sure. To merely complete all the missions (7 locations, five maps per location, 3 scenarios per map), you have 105 missions to play. Which is a lot. Missions aren't super long. The earlier maps are smaller, while as you progress they get much bigger.

Lots of different weapons customization, and the 5-point difficulty scale adds quite a significant amount of depth to the game. There are six different classes, though I must admit I never fully utilized each class to its advantage in the mobile version so this is something I seek to correct on my current PC playthrough.

At the end of the day, Breach & Clear is a game that would delight tactical strategy gamers. It can be played in short bursts, rewards planning (and risks) and has a lot of content to offer. So much of content I am sure you'll never play all the levels in the game! $15 may be a tad too high an asking price, but the $10 it is on launch sale now seems like a good trade-off.

Recommended!

reviewText:
Let me begin by saying that this game is alright. There isn't anything seriously bad about it, but there isn't much that is great either.
I bought this game during a sale for less than $5.00 and I don't think I would have paid more for it.
It's fun little game, but it feels just a step above a java game that you could play on your browser. It's pretty addicting just like some of those simple games are as well.
I haven't played a game like this before, but I hear that there are similar ones with more depth.
--WHO THIS GAME IS FOR--
Someone who is just interested in some casual tactical gaming. Pleased enough with moderate strategy gaming.

The Good:
++Levels aren't dreadfully long (about 6 minutes) but there are 7 countries to visit, each with 5 levels to play in. Also 3 game modes (Terrorist Hunt, Bomb Defusal, and Escape Plan) using same maps, This may not seem like alot but it manages to have just enough variety
++There are a lot of options with costomization and I've found myself really thinking about my purchases for guns.
--However, there is a problem with costomization that I will get into later
++Option to play with Permanent death of squad members to earn extra XP (You get a replacement if one dies but you have to rank them back up) You keep the dead members expensive weapon equipment, which is good.
++Upgrading skills for your soldiers is pretty solid with the variety of options (Responce, Accuracy, Health, Speed, Evation and an Skill that goes with the soldier's role; Like Squad Leader gets leadership skill you can upgrade). Not too easy to upgrade but not too hard.
++I like that you can assign roles to your 4 person squad (Leader, Medic, Breach, ect) and that they get perks unlocked as you level up.

The Bad:
I'm going to begine with the costomization options
++There are MANY different guns (some same price and same specs though)
On the guns you can pack them with Optics, Lasers, Grips, Flashlights, Supressors, Gas System, and Triggers
The problem is that There are only a handful of attatchments in each category and it's easy to max out on the Optics, Lasers, Grips, Flashlights. There are no tactical thinking involved in these options because they only improve accuracy and have no negatives, so you don't weigh your options. -It's pretty mindless
--The good thing is that Suppressors, Gas Systems,  and Triggers provide certain pros and cons that make you consider what perks you want and the expense of something.
There are vests and other things but to buy that are important, but there are many items like clothing, goggles and facepaint that provide NO perks.
++The Main Menu is slow and kinda laggy and brings a bad first impression when you put your mouse over a button and it takes 3 seconds for it to light up. The response when you select it is absolutely normal. But makes the game seem cheap.
++The strategy is pretty basic. I've only felt trapped and in trouble a few times. The gameplay is mostly all about keeping your guys near cover and know how to split up your guys (which isn't challenging)
If you 4 star all the maps as you progress Like I do and not jump ahead two counties (with harder soldiers) it doesn't stay very challenging. (I went two counties ahead and within two moves I was surounded and lost a guy right when he got shot at) -RIP Brett Breachers
++I'm playing the levels in Germany, (which is the 4th country) and the environment is pretty static. Only a few levels actually had 1-3 of the soldiers walking around in real time as you plan out your strategy.

THE UGLY
++The ugly part isn't in the gameplay. It is with selecting items in the market and selecting the items when you choose a new gun or add attatchments.
+The interface with the Market and costomization is terrible.
+When I purchase a new gun I have to make sure to detatch everything on the previous gun, and there isn't any fast/easy way to do it (Such as putting a small 'x' in the corner). I have to select the icon individually for Lasers, Optics, Grips ect. THEN select to 'unequip' this gets very Tedious when there are 7 attachment types.
+The interface only shows you the picture of what items are attached to your gun with no name of them or what their specs are.
+You have to go to unequip it and then mouse over it to view its specs.
+Another problem is that it doesn't tell you the name of what gun your soldier is equiped with. You have to memorize its shape and look in the market so you can compare it to a new weapon.
+When you want to compare weapons in the market you can't do it side by side. You have to click the gun, then scoll down/up the list to view the next one. That is teious as well.

CONCLUSION:
I give the game a 6.5/10 -Would not pay $15.00, wait for a sale of less than $7 if you aren't sure about this. Addicting to play but almost too simple to call it a strategy game.

+It needs improvements to make the game more interesting and needs its interface to be changed.
+Would be interesting to add multiplayer of terrorists vs Spec Ops. Where each team has to make their moves and then it plays out.

reviewText: Fun arcade-style squad-based tactical house clearance simulator. Apparently also available for iOS, but the PC version is stimulating enough to provide balanced challenge across all levels of difficulty. Squad customization is moderately deep, but there simply aren't enough options for equipment and gear to make it a true tactics sim. Some of the animations are a little buggy, and the whole game feels like it's not quite polished. The maps are pretty well made and provide good variation in theme and replayability. Some are a little hard to read or see clearly but they are great for the current game - but again, they lack the depth of strategic options that I would like. NOT WORTH current price (15$), but definitely give it a shot if you've got 8$ and want to feel like a total badass.

reviewText: I recommend the game HOWEVER it needs a balance patch. PDW or the P90 is too easy to use, just add a -0.2 gas system and you get the fastest rate of fire in the game which is 0.01 ROF. Also, snipers are WAY too underpowered, low dmg when it hits, low accuracy at long ranges. stats should be increased twicefold to like 150 ACC and 200 DMG(around 2 hits long range and crits close range?) which makes this the lowest DPS in the game and hense the worst gun in the game. If you are only going to get it for supression on the germany maps, i mean theres no point since in 5-6 moves my team will probably finish the game by then. Shotguns should also have their dmg increased since they are also rather weak due to low ROF. you should remove the birdshot feature(cone dmg to room) and go with buckshot. perhaps like a high dmg close range to justify the worth but i guess overall right now its usable.(perhaps intended feature for clearing crowded rooms? useless when shooting on the move and turning a corner, able to get one shot off before enemy takes him down.) Anyways looking aside these recommends, a good game!

reviewText:
Breach and Clear is a game that I wouldn't expect to be awesome. The simple yet expansive ideas it brings to the table makes it the best (if not one of the best) games I've ever spent $5-10 on.

Pros:
+Artwork is really nice.
+Seemingly endless customization. You pick a spec op group (I think there's 5). You pick out a pre-made face for that person. You pick out each individual person for your 4 person squad. Each spec op class has specific duties. There are more than 4 different classes, so it forces you to be creative with your team.
+ Each person carries weapons, apparel, and equipment that you personally customize for them. You can buy and sell all of these at the marketplace.
+If you want to earn money you can grind on any particular mission. Also, these missions have slightly radomized locations for your targets.
+There are 3 different mission types and each type has 7 locations and 5 missions per location.
+You can create and switch between multiple squads.
+Great tutorial

Cons:
-I almost went insane trying to get 4 stars in some levels due to the slightly randomized target location.
-Some of the guns don't get the stats they deserve. Primarily in range and damage.

9.75/10

reviewText:
Good game for players looking for some easy tactical combat. You get to command squad of four elite soldiers in various missions. There are a lot of missions to complete and they are fast going, so it is good for casual players. All missions come in three variants - kill all bad guys, find and defuse bomb (just like kill all but additionally defuse), escape (kind of wierd, you need to quite the map full of bad guys as they ambushed your team).

Tactical combat is easy - you set path of move for your soldiers and what way they look, they will attack themself. There is cover system easy to use, so your soldier hide behind walls, or some low covers and keep shooting, you can also open doors and shoot inside the room.

You get to equip your team with vests, weapons, consumables like granades or medkits and few just wardrobe items. What bothers me is a complete lack of any description of the items, like there is energy drink consumable but I have no idea what it does and why take red bull instead of frag or medkit ...
Lack of descriptions gets a bit worse when it comes to guns, they have stats, so you would think that more the better yes? Well not always, you wanna get more accuracy, but you wanna lower your ROF because the lower ROF the faster soldier states, although descriptions states *increases the amount of rounds being fired*, wierd. It would be also nice to see before buying a gun what attachments it accepts, I have busted some resource cash on guns with nice stats but without option to use silencer.

All in all it is nice game. I recommend it.

Few ideas what could be improved in the game:
-difficulty balancing (even without best guns and top levels of soldiers you can easly clear highest difficulties)
-limit FOW to soldier sight, not to open doors (I can sometimes see what's inside very last room because some terrorist opened doors to it, and none of my soldier have line of sight there)
-possibility to switch soldier in team, as of now you create squad of four and only that four can be in that squad for ever.

reviewText: I very much enjoyed this game, which is interesting because I haven't seen an RTS done in this way before. The combat was very good and provided room to run different strategies many times on the same level. Personally I found that the difficulty of the levels varied significantly. For example, for the Germany missions, I had to use 5 defibrilators and had to replay the previous missions to purchase the sniper rifle to be able to complete them on EASY. Whereas with the subsequent Russia missions, it was basically the Afghanistan missions with more enemies. I liked that you have a variety of teams to choose from (Even though the majority are American), and I hope that they add more operators in the future. One thing I  did not like was that there is very little variety in the weapons. Every unit other than JTF2 gets an M4 SOPMOD as their original weapon (Including the SAS, KSK and Spetznaz), and then, when you choose to upgrade your weapons, almost all of the weapons are SCAR, M1014 or AR15 based weapons. The ONLY exceptions are the pump action shotguns, the AWP, the LaRue OBR 7.62, the MK48 and the P90. Not a single AK, L85 or G36 based weapon in sight. Honestly, the lack of accuracy with weapons bugged me a lot more than it would probably bug other people. All in all, its a solid game but it could use or could have used some work in my opinion. 6.5-10

reviewText: Amazing game with some awesome mechanics. But if you love just trying to complete mission after mission while trying to reach the max ranking (4 stars) then look no further. Overall though one of my favorite purchases on steam!

reviewText:
This was one of the most addicting games I've ever played. I usually don't like this style of game and I wasn't expecting much when I purchased it, but I was quite impressed.

The amount of customization is enough to keep you occupied for hours. There are several special forces factions to choose from, each having a minor stat boost to differentiate from the others. You can customize every soldier in your squad, unfortunately you do have to pick from premade looks but there's so many that it's not that big of a deal. After you've given your soldier his look you can pick one of the classes/roles, each having their own bonuses and skills that unlock as you level the soldier up. Then there is gun customization, there are a lot of guns to choose from, though it can take a while to unlock some of them. Unfortunately most of the guns are just different versions of the same gun with different stats. Furthermore you can equip scopes, lasers, flash lights, triggers, grips, and even change the gas system. After you have your soldiers outfitted with guns there are several helmets, vests, camos, etc. to choose from. It's really amazing for such a small game to have customization that rivals games like Battlefield.

The gameplay is fun and thoughtful planning is your best weapon. Once you get a handle of the game the earlier difficulty levels can become sort of a faceroll, but don't worry there's multiple difficulty levels and you can tell a difference on each one. If you want to make it even harder on yourself you can select the permanent death option which is exactly as it sounds, contrary to the regular mode where your soldier will just be out of that battle but back again after the mission is over. I've always been a fan of hardcore modes in games so this was a great feature for me, though it caused me some pain a few times when I had almost max level soldiers die, then had to replace them with a fresh level 1.

My only issue with the game is there is I guess you could say an OP" gun. I will not list which gun this is as I don't want to ruin anyones experience with the game. But once I outfitted all four of my soldiers with this gun the game was too easy even on the hardest difficulties.

All in all

reviewText: I had this game first on my iPhone and have practically beaten it there and I can start off by saying that this is a nice port from mobile to PC. I liked that I wasnt forced to pay for half of the content like in the mobile version, where you had to pay for 2 squads (KSK and Spetsnaz), clothing and headgear, along with the Russian and Colombian locations. I liked playing with the content I havent purchased on mobile. I did buy the Frozen Synapse DLC and really liked the level design so far. Overall if you are a fan of these types of games I would highly reccomend. The customization of your own squad is a really cool feature, being able to use different uniforms and body armor, plus brightly colored guns. Not very difficult to play at first, but as you play higher difficulties it does require some tactics to overcome the many enemies you will find in those insane-level missions. Overall a 9/10. Fun tactical turn based strategy dosent take long to learn, with plenty of replayability once you have maxed out one squad. Just move on to another. Once my Rangers are level 30, ill be working on my Spetsnaz squad.

reviewText: This game offers a unique mix of real time combat and turn based movement. It can be quite challenging on the higher difficulties. With a variety of gameplay modes and missions to choose from, the game has more than decent replay value. My only gripe is that there is no multiplayer support, and that full price ($14.99 USD) is a little steep for what it is. However, putting this game on your wishlist and waiting for a sale is never a bad idea (i paid $3.74).

reviewText:
TL;DR: Great light strategy game that will be very addicting for the first few hours for most. In a nutshell, it is a turn based strategy game in which you must complete levels to unlock new and better stuff, to be able to accomplish new and harder levels! Standard procedure really.

Breach and Clear (B&C) is a port of what was original a mobile game (IOS, Android). It does have added content, however its origins still show through its simpicity. The graphics are decent and hold up to HD displays. but this the main improvement. It depicts multiple representations of real world Special Operations groups in a variety of environments, with the player being the commander that holds an eagle eye of the battlefield. The authenticity of much of the info in the game (such as the loading screen tips) is indeed relevant and true to modern day SOF, although the tactics" the game pushes aren't necessarily completely accurate due to the reliance on user input of what to do.

Technical Performance: Although I am running this on "gaming" (albeit aging) hardware

reviewText:
A nice little turn based tactical squad shooter. Gameplay is in the title, you're counter terrorists breaching an area and clearing it out.

It gets a little more complicated than that of course, who goes in first, what weapon they're equipped with, how long you look at an area, you plan it out hit Breach" and watch it all go to plan. Or all go to hell if you didn't take into account a possible sniper.

It's not as good as Frozen Synapse

reviewText: This game offers many options to conquer a challenge in a grid based map, turn-based overhead tactical game. The game alllows for very fast progress, and you can get into it very quickly. It allows for the option of class specialization, and that prompts you to create new squads for different mission scenarios. I highly recommend getting the Frozen Synapse DLC if you don't own Frozen Synapse. Ultimately, this game is very well put together, although, the UI might be able to use some work to make it more convenient, but that's my only complaint with it.

reviewText:
It's a port from mobile. The enemy AI is kind of a joke and you have no way to tell your guys to hold fire. They spray lead at everything in their view instead of waiting to get in to a superior position. This often leads to them taking unnecessary damage and is tactically idiotic.
Example: 4 tango with backs to entry point. Your team enters and opens fire as soon as they enter while moving to cover. They kill all 4 tangos but take damage in the exchange of gunfire. Had they held fire till in cover, they would be far less likey to take damage while maintaining their advantage of surprise and position.

Game lacks go codes" like Door Kickers does so well. In the planning stage
date: there is no time representation so you can't see how many seconds it will take to move someone to a position. No hold position/delay for X time command. No shoot at this target till threat is removed
recommended:
then continue with plan. You can't pick which targets to shoot at so no way to prioritize targets. Therefore you can't tell your guys to focus the sniper standing in the open vs the shotguner in heavy cover who happends to be a bit closer.

Another glaring problem is that every gun unlocked after the CTAR has not been an upgrade. Currently at 472 stars. Laughing at how many stars are required to unlock the later shotguns. Game is getting far too boring and repetitive to ever reach 1400 let alone the 2100 for the last rifle.

From the Devs "The higher star guns are more for 'prestige' than anything else. They were added as    a prize for fans who wanted something out of the ordinary
hoursPlayed:
so they are camouflaged or Platinum/Gold versions of earlier guns."
Prestige in a single player game? Umm OK.

No way to tell what is required to reach 4 stars on any given map. Every map and scenario has different requirements

reviewText: I recommend the game HOWEVER it needs a balance patch. PDW or the P90 is too easy to use, just add a -0.2 gas system and you get the fastest rate of fire in the game which is 0.01 ROF. I mean who cares about the -30 accuracy when you can just spray like a noob =) and steamroll room after room. Also, snipers are WAY too underpowered, low dmg when it hits, low accuracy at long ranges. stats should be increased twicefold to like 150 ACC and 200 DMG(around 2 hits long range and crits close range?) which makes this the lowest DPS in the game and hense the worst gun in the game. If you are only going to get it for supression on the germany maps, i mean theres no point since in 5-6 moves my team will probably finish the game by then. Shotguns should also have their dmg increased since they are also rather weak due to low ROF. you should remove the birdshot feature(cone dmg to room) and go with buckshot. perhaps like a high dmg close range to justify the worth but i guess overall right now its usable.(perhaps intended feature for clearing crowded rooms? useless when shooting on the move and turning a corner, able to get one shot off before enemy takes him down.) Anyways looking aside these recommends, a good game!

reviewText:
Enjoyable round-based tactics game. It's not an in-depth strategy/tactics game like Jagged Alliance 1&2 and even less complex than XCOM:Enemy Unknown, but it's still a fun game that applies the same principle: find the right mix of weapons, skills and positioning to beat the opposition. Since you can't target enemies and have to rely on your squad to pick the targets, positioning and telling your squad where to look is key. Your options may be reduced, but it's also focussed and does this part really well. The pacing for unlocks is also done in a good way, by completing missions and doing well in them you earn stars which in turn unlock equipment for your team. Since you can jump in and out of campaigns it's a game you don't necessarily need to play for longer sessions, you can just jump in and play for 10 minutes and still finish a mission or two.

The price in comparison to the mobile version is also not as horrible as it seems at first glance since you get alot more content than the mobile base version has.

My main complaint about this game would be the lack of information or tool tips. Some things are left unexplained an you have to figure it out yourself, some information is only available on the loading screens - which you will never get to read on a modern gaming PC, because they pass by in seconds. Some might see that as an oldschool approach to game design, but that doesn't make it any better.

On the technical side this game is a port from a mobile platform and it shows. The graphics are simply outdated, the variety of animations is very limited. On the plus side the optimization seems to be decent, so loading times are swift and the performance is very good, even on older machines. The sound design is okay, too. Balance is ok, music isn't annoying, shots go pop and grenades go bang, some radio communication inbetween. Nothing special, but it works.

In about 11 hours of playtime I have experienced one interface freeze, but no crashes, sound loops or graphical errors. And this also gives you a rough estimate of playtime: if you like round based tactics, this will entertain you for ten to 15 hours, depending on how much you are into unlocks and earnings stars.

Overall this isn't a contender for GOTY, but a enjoyable round based snack for inbetween and at 9€ this was worthy buy.

reviewText:
The game is fantastic, just like I expected. I personally don't have an iOS or Android device, so I wasn't able to play the game prior to its PC release.

This game simulates rapid close quarter engagements from a top down view. You as the player controls a squad of elite counter-terrorist forces. Using careful movement and tactics, your goal is to move throughout a building complex and eliminate all hostiles as fast as possible.

The different factions you can play as gives me a really nice immersive feel when I give my men orders. It's not just an aesthetic thing either, every faction has a different stat bonus. For example, the British SAS specializes in Evasion.

If you're looking for a good top-down tactical shooter (or disappointed with Black Ops II's Strike Force missions), this is most definitely for you. Do not jump into this game thinking you can force your men in rooms like supermen and expect them to go gun blazing, killing terrorists.

My only gripe with this game is that the game freezes up my computer during the after action reports, forcing me to use task manager to close the game. Devs, get this nuisance out of the way, periodically update it with new content, and you have yourself a AAA quality indie game.

reviewText:
The first time I played Breach & Clear (B&C) was on iOS, I was a bit dubious as it was a turn based game as these are not to my style, but I tired it and was instantly hooked from the first mission.

I’d also recommend this if you were a fan of games like Swat 4 and Older Rainbow Six games where it was about planning your moves to get the best result, as it will take some skill to get a 4 Star rating on the B&C missions.

But if you were thinking I’ve got the iOS version so why would I need to buy it again?

Well, it’s bigger than the iOS with more mission and gear as standard plus panning the camera and planning is made easier with mouse and keyboard support.

So Stack Up, Breach & Clear…

reviewText: Yes, as some others have said the game is a little simplistic.  Small maps and almost no permanence from engagement to engagement, aside from your squad's skills.  It is still wildly fun and engaging.  Despite their small size, some of the maps offer complex challenges, if you want to maximize your score.  The loadout options are widly varied, as are the specialties and skill allocations.  Is it XCOM or Jagged Alliance?  No.  But it is still a lot of fun, when you want a moderately deep, engaging, turn-based shooter conveniently delivered in bite-sized (<10min per mission) chunks.

reviewText:
A fantastic game that truly is worth the price you pay. It contains fun squad tactics and a nice customization system, however it does not have any base manage ment and I felt very little difference between each soldier also my UI seems to be a little bugged my weapon attachments for trigger and gass system does not show me what I have equiped (just the blank grey slot). Overall there are some Improvesments that would help this game apeal more (base management, some sort of global event system with a persistent story line that drives the missions, a way to move soldiers from one squad to another, squad wipes [yes there is NO WAY to wipe out your squad one will always survive even with perma death enabled], and a way to delete squads, oh and  better UI for PC) I give it a 5.7/10.

(after a few more hours and an update)

The experience can grow old a little bit after you reach that 5 hour play time mark when it comes to your squads. I just feel there isn't that much variety with the soldiers (and even the squads for that matter), a perfect way to fix this is to allow players to move soldiers around from squad to squad revamp the whole system. If the changes were up to me I would make it so you buy squad slots" and soldiers. So instead of having a squads with just one type of nationality you just buy a squad slot that allows you to have a squad then you buy men from the factions (S.A.S
recommended: etc) this way you can have an intelligence officer and a weapon sergeant from from say JTF2 a SL from the Rangers and a breacher from the Seals. This is just a quick raw idea to give the players more dimensions to play with. The replayability of the missions is quite high and still very enjoyable I didn't think it would be so since you don't really have that many maps to choose from but the random enemy position with different game modes (well done with the game modes devs
hoursPlayed: I would like to see more of those maybe a hostage rescue game) really make this game experience last. So tho the squads are quite lacking the fact that it got me hooked until now forces me to give it a new rating of a solid 7/10 (which surpasses the rating I gave X-Com 6.3 not saying BNC is better it just gave me more fun for allot longer than X-Com did

reviewText: I very much enjoyed this game, which is interesting because I haven't seen an RTS done in this way before. The combat was very good and provided room to run different strategies many times on the same level. Personally I found that the difficulty of the levels varied significantly. For example, for the Germany missions, I had to use 5 defibrilators and had to replay the previous missions to purchase the sniper rifle to be able to complete them on EASY. Whereas with the subsequent Russia missions, it was basically the Afghanistan missions with more enemies. I liked that you have a variety of teams to choose from (Even though the majority are American), and I hope that they add more operators in the future. One thing I  did not like was that there is very little variety in the weapons. Every unit other than JTF2 gets an M4 SOPMOD as their original weapon (Including the SAS, KSK and Spetznaz), and then, when you choose to upgrade your weapons, almost all of the weapons are SCAR, M1014 or AR15 based weapons. The ONLY exceptions are the pump action shotguns, the AWP, the LaRue OBR 7.62, the MK48 and the P90. Not a single AK, L85 or G36 based weapon in sight. Honestly, the lack of accuracy with weapons bugged me a lot more than it would probably bug other people. All in all, its a solid game but it could use or could have used some work in my opinion. 6.5-10

reviewText:
Really fun tactical, turn-based, game!

Despite it being a port from the iPad the devs have done a surprsingly good job getting it fit for the PC platform.
Sure, there are bugs here and there but the developers are constantly adding stuff, like more spec-ops units and guns for example.

The game itself is pretty solid, graphics-wise there's alot to wish for but other than that the game fluids well.
Breach and Clear features some basic customization like choosing headgear, facegear, vests and clothing/uniform.
You can also recolor the guns to fit the environment etc.
Gun customization ranges from scopes/sights to IR gear, silencers, triggers and gas systems.
(I might've forgot one or two things, point is that you can really make modify a gun to be all ~tier1~.)

The turn system and waypoint system works well, it actually feels like cover gives your soldiers (and the enemies) realistic protection from bullets (on a basic scale though).

Also, the soundtracks in this game is really good, really adds to that intense feeling when you're planning the perfect endgame move at the end of a hard mission!


All in all i seriously recommend this if you want some hours of fun, definietly worth the low cost.

reviewText:
This was one of the most addicting games I've ever played. I usually don't like this style of game and I wasn't expecting much when I purchased it, but I was quite impressed.

The amount of customization is enough to keep you occupied for hours. There are several special forces factions to choose from, each having a minor stat boost to differentiate from the others. You can customize every soldier in your squad, unfortunately you do have to pick from premade looks but there's so many that it's not that big of a deal. After you've given your soldier his look you can pick one of the classes/roles, each having their own bonuses and skills that unlock as you level the soldier up. Then there is gun customization, there are a lot of guns to choose from, though it can take a while to unlock some of them. Unfortunately most of the guns are just different versions of the same gun with different stats. Furthermore you can equip scopes, lasers, flash lights, triggers, grips, and even change the gas system. After you have your soldiers outfitted with guns there are several helmets, vests, camos, etc. to choose from. It's really amazing for such a small game to have customization that rivals games like Battlefield.

The gameplay is fun and thoughtful planning is your best weapon. Once you get a handle of the game the earlier difficulty levels can become sort of a faceroll, but don't worry there's multiple difficulty levels and you can tell a difference on each one. If you want to make it even harder on yourself you can select the permanent death option which is exactly as it sounds, contrary to the regular mode where your soldier will just be out of that battle but back again after the mission is over. I've always been a fan of hardcore modes in games so this was a great feature for me, though it caused me some pain a few times when I had almost max level soldiers die, then had to replace them with a fresh level 1.

My only issue with the game is there is I guess you could say an OP" gun. I will not list which gun this is as I don't want to ruin anyones experience with the game. But once I outfitted all four of my soldiers with this gun the game was too easy even on the hardest difficulties.

All in all

reviewText:
Breach & Clear sounds complicated but I can assure you it is not. The game is a simple tactical game based on movement and angle of sight. Levelling up your soldiers makes the game enjoyable. However the game does feel it is missing more content, like more mission or even more perks for your soldiers. There is plenty of gear to purchase using you well rewarded in-game cash. There is also a large range of mods for your chosen guns.

The graphics are simple with only little bit of detail but enough for the game to look good.

The sound effects are very simple specially the environmental tracks while playing the missions.
The gun shot effects are again simple but effective.

Controls with the mouse can get a little annoying at times. When you try to move the camera around you will regularly place a move node for one of you soldiers.

I do recommend this game because it is fun and enjoyable to play but the game does feel cheaper the its current price tag of £10.99p.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Realistic take on CQB action.
+ WEGO format, giving both the satisfying action of CQB and the chance to contemplate and plan tactics for your troops.
+ Typical scenario is short enough to be played as a quick, yet satisfying, lunchbreak distraction.

Cons:
- No complete replay feature (a la Doorkickers), you can only view replay the last turn.
- Graphics is spartan. Even the program icon (at least in the Mac version) is low-res and looks ugly compared to other icons.
- Different special forces options doesn't seem to offer much difference in gameplay.

Bottomline:
This is a perfect game for those of us who wished to relive the glory days of realistic FPS (e.g. the original Rainbow Six) but who no longer have either the time, reflexes nor sufficient computing power to play the current batch of FPS.

reviewText:
It's a port from mobile. The enemy AI is kind of a joke and you have no way to tell your guys to hold fire. They spray lead at everything in their view instead of waiting to get in to a superior position. This often leads to them taking unnecessary damage and is tactically idiotic.
Example: 4 tango with backs to entry point. Your team enters and opens fire as soon as they enter while moving to cover. They kill all 4 tangos but take damage in the exchange of gunfire. Had they held fire till in cover, they would be far less likey to take damage while maintaining their advantage of surprise and position.

Game lacks go codes" like Door Kickers does so well. In the planning stage
date: there is no time representation so you can't see how many seconds it will take to move someone to a position. No hold position/delay for X time command. No shoot at this target till threat is removed
recommended:
then continue with plan. You can't pick which targets to shoot at so no way to prioritize targets. Therefore you can't tell your guys to focus the sniper standing in the open vs the shotguner in heavy cover who happends to be a bit closer.

Another glaring problem is that every gun unlocked after the CTAR has not been an upgrade. Currently at 472 stars. Laughing at how many stars are required to unlock the later shotguns. Game is getting far too boring and repetitive to ever reach 1400 let alone the 2100 for the last rifle.

From the Devs "The higher star guns are more for 'prestige' than anything else. They were added as    a prize for fans who wanted something out of the ordinary
hoursPlayed:
so they are camouflaged or Platinum/Gold versions of earlier guns."
Prestige in a single player game? Umm OK.

No way to tell what is required to reach 4 stars on any given map. Every map and scenario has different requirements
voteText: but game fails to tell you what you are aiming for.  Use an item on one map
helpfulPercent: ok. Use the same item on another and lose a star but won't tell you are being deducted. Did I get 3 stars on my last try because I didn't make time or due to using an item? No Fn idea. Huge fail IMO.\n\nNot enough variety of weapons. One assault rifle after another. Outside of the of the P90

votesTotal: MP7A1 or UMP. Guess this is due to the squads being military and not law enforcement. These are guns I would expect to find in the arsenal of a game that focuses on CQB regadless of the operators.\n\nGame is more arcade'ish than tactically sound. Glad I picked this up at 75% off."

reviewText:
Breach & Clear is a tactical turn based strategy game similar in execution to XCOM. You take command of a special forces squad of your choosing, and plan your attack on objective based missions (terrorist hunt, bomb defusal or extraction). You have a reasonably wide selection of weapons available, though weapons used by some special forces are absent from the game. Enemy engagements are always lethal, as there is no option to simply incapacitate. The inability to set timings is also detrimental to tactics.

Overall the game is entertaining enough to keep you playing for hours, but it lacks scope and depth in comparison to tactical predecessors such as Deadline (1996, Millennium Interactive). The graphics and audio are good, but I'd like to see some destructability, and a greater range of weapons and consumables (no smoke grenades or CS gas?).

7/10 - Still playing it.

Breach & Clear sounds complicated but I can assure you it is not. The game is a simple tactical game based on movement and angle of sight. Levelling up your soldiers makes the game enjoyable. I do recommend this game because it is fun and enjoyable to play but the game does feel cheaper the its current price tag of £10.99p.
