reviewText:
Enjoyable round-based tactics game. It's not an in-depth strategy/tactics game like Jagged Alliance 1&2 and even less complex than XCOM:Enemy Unknown, but it's still a fun game that applies the same principle: find the right mix of weapons, skills and positioning to beat the opposition. Since you can't target enemies and have to rely on your squad to pick the targets, positioning and telling your squad where to look is key. Your options may be reduced, but it's also focussed and does this part really well. The pacing for unlocks is also done in a good way, by completing missions and doing well in them you earn stars which in turn unlock equipment for your team. Since you can jump in and out of campaigns it's a game you don't necessarily need to play for longer sessions, you can just jump in and play for 10 minutes and still finish a mission or two.

The price in comparison to the mobile version is also not as horrible as it seems at first glance since you get alot more content than the mobile base version has.

My main complaint about this game would be the lack of information or tool tips. Some things are left unexplained an you have to figure it out yourself, some information is only available on the loading screens - which you will never get to read on a modern gaming PC, because they pass by in seconds. Some might see that as an oldschool approach to game design, but that doesn't make it any better.

On the technical side this game is a port from a mobile platform and it shows. The graphics are simply outdated, the variety of animations is very limited. On the plus side the optimization seems to be decent, so loading times are swift and the performance is very good, even on older machines. The sound design is okay, too. Balance is ok, music isn't annoying, shots go pop and grenades go bang, some radio communication inbetween. Nothing special, but it works.

In about 11 hours of playtime I have experienced one interface freeze, but no crashes, sound loops or graphical errors. And this also gives you a rough estimate of playtime: if you like round based tactics, this will entertain you for ten to 15 hours, depending on how much you are into unlocks and earnings stars.

Overall this isn't a contender for GOTY, but a enjoyable round based snack for inbetween and at 9€ this was worthy buy.

reviewText:
The game is fantastic, just like I expected. I personally don't have an iOS or Android device, so I wasn't able to play the game prior to its PC release.

This game simulates rapid close quarter engagements from a top down view. You as the player controls a squad of elite counter-terrorist forces. Using careful movement and tactics, your goal is to move throughout a building complex and eliminate all hostiles as fast as possible.

The different factions you can play as gives me a really nice immersive feel when I give my men orders. It's not just an aesthetic thing either, every faction has a different stat bonus. For example, the British SAS specializes in Evasion.

If you're looking for a good top-down tactical shooter (or disappointed with Black Ops II's Strike Force missions), this is most definitely for you. Do not jump into this game thinking you can force your men in rooms like supermen and expect them to go gun blazing, killing terrorists.

My only gripe with this game is that the game freezes up my computer during the after action reports, forcing me to use task manager to close the game. Devs, get this nuisance out of the way, periodically update it with new content, and you have yourself a AAA quality indie game.

But if you were thinking I’ve got the iOS version so why would I need to buy it again?

Well, it’s bigger than the iOS with more mission and gear as standard plus panning the camera and planning is made easier with mouse and keyboard support.

So Stack Up, Breach & Clear…

reviewText:
Really fun tactical, turn-based, game!

Despite it being a port from the iPad the devs have done a surprsingly good job getting it fit for the PC platform.
Sure, there are bugs here and there but the developers are constantly adding stuff, like more spec-ops units and guns for example.

The game itself is pretty solid, graphics-wise there's alot to wish for but other than that the game fluids well.
Breach and Clear features some basic customization like choosing headgear, facegear, vests and clothing/uniform.
You can also recolor the guns to fit the environment etc.
Gun customization ranges from scopes/sights to IR gear, silencers, triggers and gas systems.
(I might've forgot one or two things, point is that you can really make modify a gun to be all ~tier1~.)

The turn system and waypoint system works well, it actually feels like cover gives your soldiers (and the enemies) realistic protection from bullets (on a basic scale though).

Also, the soundtracks in this game is really good, really adds to that intense feeling when you're planning the perfect endgame move at the end of a hard mission!


All in all i seriously recommend this if you want some hours of fun, definietly worth the low cost.

reviewText:
I thought I would give this game a try for 30 mins.... but spent the whole night playing it. It is a very tactical turn based shooter that forces you to consider kill zones, weight of fire, flanking and cover.

It seems very minimalist, but very smooth, slick and stable as a game. The initial simplicity of the game disguises how complex the tactics will become.

As the missions get harder you realise its all about the real tactics of Close Quarters Combat ... you need maximum fire power on your enemies, whilst denying the enemy of the same. You need to move forward aggressively to take the initiative but not kamikaze into enemy fire. You need to exploit cover, but flank your enemy so they are being fired upon from multiple directions.

.... and with every map you are forced to chose between splitting your forces, and getting better possibilities of flanking action, but by doing so, you split up your squad, and reduce their weight of fire.

There is also an RPG aspect to the game. As you level up you unlock weapons and earn money, which you can spend on buying kit for you squad. As your progress you can buy better guns, armour, helmets, and accessories for your weapons, consumables for your missions and vanity items like clothing and face masks. You have to chose wisely though as often it a choice between better low level kit across the squad.. or one great upgrade for one guy. Spending your money wisely is part of the game.

Im really surprised how great this game is ... its a brilliant tactical shooter.

reviewText:
Pretty entertaining game. With many maps and modes and the ability to create multiple Special Forces Squads from all around the world (like Rangers, KsK,SaS or Speznaz). You can choose from different roles and customize your character.
The gameplay itself is pretty solid too.

But it could be better, the game lacks a lot of things, like:

More weapon variety, most guns are rifles based of the american M4 or other similar guns. Only one PDW (P90) no MP5 or Mp7 only one sniper (an artic warfare i think)  (with no real sniper role).
Gameplay is very basic it lacks the option to set timers on waypoints for example so that your guys don't enter before a flash. It's basically just kick in that door, clear room, repeat. No rappeling down walls, no breaches trough windows (there are none) it's all basic.
Graphics and effects are basic too (i miss some bullet holes, blood and destruction, would be a nice touch).

But the things that are there work and it'S entertainig for a while. I recommend buying it when it's on sale but don't expect too much!


To the developer: a stram workshop for this game would be awesome, we could make new maps, weapons etc.

reviewText:
Solid tactical shootymans action, playable on old and underpowered hardware.  Design is tight and levels are short, if it took less time to load and exit I'd call it a coffee-break game. If you played X-COM Enemy Unknown/Within and thought the battles needed to be shorter and tighter, give this one a shot.

The main draw for most people is probably going to be gun porn, there are dozens of gun and gear options, most of which only require the money you get from clearing missions.  Additional guns, however, are unlocked by scoring well on those missions.  It's a cumulative thing, so if you do horribly on 10-20 missions, you get the same gun as if you did great on five missions.  And of course you can replay the missions to get better rankings.

Sound design is nothing to write home about. Guns go bang (or more of a clank when suppressed), terrorists go ow, your soldiers deliver canned soundbites, music is the generic vaguely patriotic military score.  It doesn't interfere with the experience.

reviewText:
=HEADS UP=
This Review is about my Opinion. If you disagree with the Opinion that is just fine. Give my review a dislike and move on. But if you feel the need to insult me or cannot be reasoned with when you comment i will take my Right as Reviewmaker to block you. This does not apply to people who simply want to discuss.

=REVIEW=
So this game is ok. That is all i can say about it in short. But lets go on to the longer part.

The game is good but its nothing for the long run. It is an interesting concept but in the end the same thing over and over again. It gets boring rather quickly and i say its not worth 15€. If anything buy it when it is on sale if you even want to buy it.

The games gameplay overall is ok but like i said before, it gets boring rather quickly. You have a set amount of maps/missions that you go through and of course they get harder. To beat harder difficulties though you have to grind alot to buy your team equipment. Grinding in this game either to level up your character or to buy more things is a big part of this game. And required on higher difficulties. Without it you will have a hard time of surviving.

To wrap it up: This game is not worth 15€. If you see it on sale but you have another game you want to buy with an equal price then go ahead and buy the other game.

reviewText:
I thought I would give this game a try for 30 mins.... but spent the whole night playing it. It is a very tactical turn based shooter that forces you to consider kill zones, weight of fire, flanking and cover.

It seems very minimalist, but very smooth, slick and stable as a game. The initial simplicity of the game disguises how complex the tactics will become.

As the missions get harder you realise its all about the real tactics of Close Quarters Combat ... you need maximum fire power on your enemies, whilst denying the enemy of the same. You need to move forward aggressively to take the initiative but not kamikaze into enemy fire. You need to exploit cover, but flank your enemy so they are being fired upon from multiple directions.

.... and with every map you are forced to chose between splitting your forces, and getting better possibilities of flanking action, but by doing so, you split up your squad, and reduce their weight of fire.

There is also an RPG aspect to the game. As you level up you unlock weapons and earn money, which you can spend on buying kit for you squad. As your progress you can buy better guns, armour, helmets, and accessories for your weapons, consumables for your missions and vanity items like clothing and face masks. You have to chose wisely though as often it a choice between better low level kit across the squad.. or one great upgrade for one guy. Spending your money wisely is part of the game.

Im really surprised how great this game is ... its a brilliant tactical shooter.

reviewText:
While I wouldn't necessarily compare the game to X-Com, neither new nor old, it is hard not to draw some parallels, considering both are Turnbased Tactics games. Breach & Clear has more in common with Frozen Synapse than it does have in common with X-Com though.

The gameplay is rather simple. Enemies are randomly seeded into a map, where they will do their terroristy things like inspecting the carpet in an otherwise empty room, and you are tasked with clearing the bad guys, finding a hostage/bomb or escaping to an exfil location. The random seeding of the enemy gives the game quite a bit of replay-ability.

Each level has one or more entry points and you as the player are tasked with dividing your 4 people team among the entry points and then go from there. You plan each move in its entirety and then once you have planned it, you execute said plan. Covering all the angels, trying to use cover to your advantage or throw flashbangs or regular grenades into an area to deal with the enemy.

The game's simplicity is also its strength. Nobody ever said that chess was a boring game because it had a bunch of simple rules and Breach & Clear is like that as well. You do have a couple tactical options but for the most part its simple facing, facing and positioning, that wins the day.

Graphically the game isn't impressive, but being a spiritual successor to Frozen Synapse it is still a step up from a blue backdrop and green and red enemies. Also I can't quite put my finger on it, why I am liking this game more than I did Frozen Synapse, but I also couldn't name any real difference between the two other than Breach & Clear having the more appealing aesthetic.

Breach & Clear also offers a class and level system, with your team getting more experienced and unlocking more abilities. And there is a shop allowing you to buy new unlocked weapons, equipment and cosmetic items.

All in all a solid game with, at the very least, the early missions taking about 10 to 15 minutes tops.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Command a squad of elite OPERATORS against various terrorist threats.
Choose your SF background - SEALs, DEVGRU, SAS, Spetsnaz, and more.
Customise everything: faces and names, weapons, weapon mods, armor, equipment, classes, stats, and hats.

Squad members are saved to a profile and can level up, but there's also a permadeath option if that's your style.

Combat is top-down, divided into turns of a few seconds each, much like Frozen Synapse - but less wanky.

No longer will troops stand in the open to get shot, making reaction time the only factor. Instead, you can fire from cover - from behind a wall, some crates, or from around a corner. Units have health, although it's very easy to get killed in one turn IF there's no cover.

Overcome defender's advantage through use of unit abilities, grenades, cover, and flanking. The superior training of your operators sometimes helps, but only superior tactics will carry the day.

Buy this. It's Frozen Synapse with better graphics, gameplay, customisation, characters, and no silly story.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
If you like turn based shooters, this may be a game for you. Breach & Clear is a simulator and straightforward. The marginal story only serves as a simplistic backstory to why you are in one country or another. It doesn't matter; you are there to eliminate terrorists. The story only serves to support that.

The levels are well designed and compact. Graphically the game is simplistic but they serve well enough to set the stage. The locals are diverse and enjoyable, though I found myself employing the same strategies on most occasions. Yet I suppose that’s realistic, whether it is some Russian compound or an office building the principles of clearing a building are the same. Even though the game can feel repetitive I always found myself reloading the game and coming back for more. I still am. I hope they add more maps later on. I know it is wishful thinking but it be endless fun if they added the ability to make your own scenarios and show them to your friends.

There are a handful of game modes to partake in. Such as bomb disposal, hostage rescue, and the generic eliminate all threats. There are also a handful of difficulties to take part in to test your skills.

There is also a large amount of upgrades you can do to your characters. There is also a store where you can buy new weapons, accessories, clothing, helmets, and vests. Despite the wide array of options available I never felt that my characters had unique skills that affected my gameplay substantially. I found myself using characters interchangeably regardless of how I loaded them out.

The UI is simplistic but allows a decent amount of diversity. I do wish they had a mechanism by which you could delay a characters movement. It would have been rather helpful. Overall the game has been enjoyable and I hope to get another five-ten hours out of it before I’m done with it.

reviewText:
Time Played: 7 hours as of this review.

I caught this game while it was on sale for 5$  And that was about all I'd spend on this game.

Graphically; the game uses rather dated graphics made worse by missing textures from some of it's enemies, the first few levels are the worst in that regard. Also, lacking polish in regards to the little things, one of the most clawing is the AWP sniper rifle ejecting multiple brass casings when it fires.

So, graphics aren't a deal breaker nowadays, so what's the tactical gameplay like? Basic. The game features cover, breaching tactics, and grenades, All were great in X-com: Enemy Unknown, but here they feel very contrived. I have yet to find a good position for my sniper, and enemy snipers start in very good positions. Starting positions in later levels are very impractical, leaving your squad open during the most critical entry moments.

Furthermore, any feature involving doors (any breaching methods, and the ability to wedge doors closed) are not even present in many missions because they take place outside, with no other 'breaching' methods to replace them. I figured outside grenades could serve as a breaching method, but many of the maps are designed in such a way that you cannot throw grenades directly out the doorway to clear yourself an opening.

Which brings me to enemy placement, which is randomized. Don't get me wrong, randomization brings replayability, but unless you want to spend a fifth of your mission earnings on UAVs for each mission, then you are left with no way of knowing where even basic enemies directly at your starting position are. This turns most missions into a bloody slug-fest as you pray your soldiers can even make it in the door without dying. Especially when mexican cartel snipers are far better shots than your special forces sniper with max accuracy and loaded with high-tech targeting devices.

At the end of the day, the game uses many of the tired and cheap methods of increasing difficulty that I thought we left behind in the 90s, and for me, that makes this game a far cry shy of being worth 15$.

reviewText:
I will start admitting that I do not like turn-based game (I feel as I am playing Monopoli, alone) and that I suck at strategy games (no one's perfect), I always feel like the Ai is cheating, probably because I do not get the strategy gameplay elements fast enough, no doubt.

Anyway I was pleasantly surprised that this game turn-based gameplay it's more a planifying stage of the action reminding me a lot of the good days, and actions, of Rainbow Six.
Also that the strategy elements are simple: movement, line of fire, cross-fire.

This game is actually addictive even if you are replaying the same levels at different difficulties (lot of levels).
I also apprecciated there were different gameplays, not only terrorist hunt, but bomb defusal and escape.

For stategy players it' surely boring, as it is too simple, but for a noob like me, I enjoyed a lot.
A good game, a fair price, a nice surprise.

PS: i disliked the actual values of the weapons, as the sniper rifle or the mg do not do the job they should.

reviewText: It takes a lot for a game interface to annoy me in less than 30 seconds but this game did exactly that.  There was no way to step back through the initial squad setup, so your initial choice was locked.  Afterwords, you can create a new squad for a cost of in-game currency.  Sorry, if you can't get a UX designer to figure out a common use case like stepping back through your choices, then you deserve to be sent to be returned.  'nuff said.

reviewText:
One of the most addictive tactical games ever, much like the original Rainbow Six games, just...one...more...mission.
The possibilities are endless, a great variety of teams, gear and weapons.
There are several missions types available with multiple campaigns in different worldwide locations.
AI is decent enough to make it interesting and difficult, but not too difficult on normal level.
UAV option is real nice for scouting an area before going in guns blazing (or stealthy).
A definitive Buy!!

reviewText: Never play this Genre before but I fall in love with it. You control 4 units. Each unit has its ability. Every Turn counts. Every corner matters. More detail in this game than I thought. You can upgrade your squads ( stats , gear , gun , skill ). A lot of mission. Would love if campagne available. I bought this game for 1$. Really worth a buy.\n\n8.5/10 really worth a buy while on sale.

reviewText: Very surprised to pick up this game as inexpensively as I did.  It is just the type of game I was looking for, military strategy, that doesn't require 12 hours to play.  Sometimes you want something that is deep and makes you think, but that you can play quickly.  You acn knock out a few rounds in a few minutes, or play for hours.\n\nDeep game play, lots of strategy, and replay value is high.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: Basically a casual Frozen Synapse, it offers a disappointingly clumsy and imprecise system for squad control and a tedious amount of grind for stats and items (being a port of a F2P mobile game), but at the end of the day, it's suprisingly fun casual entertainment. Just don't expect it to be a tactical simulator like it oh-so-optimistically markets itself as.
